comments.commentBody:
@Einstein – Well, it's not an article. It's a personal essay.

Personal essays often seem strange. Maybe especially when the culture they confront isn't all that familiar to readers.

In the past, in some U.S. states, suicide was a felony. I don't know how many states. Some years ago, when I was reading Depression-era newspapers on library microfilm reels, I inadvertently discovered that in Seattle in the 1930s, some of the folks who attempted suicide were arrested. The details were scant, and I can't guess whether the arrests were a form of rescue in desperate times. I like to think they were.

As for this essay — I really appreciate the caliber of Jerry Pinto's writing, his sharing of his family's experiences, the inclusion of L.'s moving recollection of his father's intervention at the police station. Not to mention learning a little more about India.

I really appreciate the writing in this piece.
This is a very strange article.
This has been going on since Reagan. We never learn.
Did you notice how many incumbents were defeated this past cycle.  The people do hold Congress accountable.
Correction: *Close* Post Offices and do the bare minimum.

It seems Conservatives around the world jumped on the Austerity bandwagon for budget deficits/ economic growth. At least that’s that they told us. What they really ended up doing - the beatings on the middle/ lower classes will continue until moral improves. Austerity hasn’t affected the top 1%, Wall St. or billion dollar corporations. All are enjoying the 2nd Gilded Age, especially in America.

If Conservatives (Dems/GOP) in the U.S. really wanted to cut the deficit, they would cut business subsidies/wars and close the tax breaks/tax havens. That would require tax reform from Congress, who were MIA the last 6 years. No way were they going to anger their constituencies. Why jeopardize their meal ticket? Their vaunted “Do nothing” status remains in-tact. So what did they do? Name Post offices and do the bare minimal.

Another easy decision was gutting domestic programs. Who needs SNAP, Planned Parenthood, teachers or long-term unemployment? Infrastructure requires spending so that never made the list. Defund CFPB, but luckily that was not under their purview.

Despite their willful neglect, a hands-off approach to business combined with rock bottom interest rates, their economy for businesses/ wealthy are back on track. For a majority of Americans, not so much.

Congress should be vilified for their ineptness and held accountable for their bad decisions, but they won’t. Instead, we have a new batch of big, bad Foxes - ready to watch the hen house and exploit the system.

Please keep in mind that the bashers, or at least the ones in Congress and state legislatures, are acting at the behest of the middle-class voters who keep idiotically electing them. The middle class gets what it votes for.

Tim,

Please keep in mind that the drop in energy costs caused by Free Market Economics has put more money in the pockets of U.S. citizens in 6 months than anything done by Government in the last 6 years. That is why we will have two quarters of good growth this year, finally.

That is also why Obama deserves none of the credit, past that which he rightly received in the November Election!

I love this column, but I wish you would have added the fact that it was, always has been, and always will be, the collective heads of the average middle classes who have been subjected to all this baseball bat bashing not the collective heads of those who decide to start or stop the bashing process. The "to bash or not to bash" committee has always been made up of members who are born with, gain, or given the necessary head gear which makes them immune to the bashing process. It is also the chosen few of this committee who actually profit from the occasional bashing.

All the complicated macro economic debates which are used as bats or reasons for bashings fade into history because voter memory is short-lived and real issues are lost in the sales rhetoric of the media tags which have become a part of our daily diet. And we are so happy when the bashing stops and pain subsides. We embrace, rejoice, celebrate like one who has just been released from hospital. We forget what made us sick or who profited from our "treatment",

Given the sorry state of our education, infrastructure, R & D and high student debt, the government doesn't even have the money for basic necessities.....

What are talking about???

"The truth - an uncomfortable one - is that our hearts have hardened and we've become even more selfish. We're no longer interested in broadly-shared prosperity, but in extracting as much from our planet and one another as possible while giving as little as we can back."

With that attitude, maybe you should start your own commune. While you're at it, give up the electronic device you used to write your opinion and give all your worldly possessions to charity. Go work in a soup kitchen and practice what you preach.

The economic system known as capitalism has brought about the fastest rise in prosperity the world has ever seen. Is it perfect? No. But Edison didn't create things to "give back" to the community. Neither did Jobs, Gates, Zuckerberg, and countless others across the globe whose main purpose was to make money. And yet the world benefitted from their discoveries and inventions. And you would call these people "selfish". Get a grip.

You may have missed the news.  The final verdict is in on Keynesian economics - it does not work here or anywhere else in the world where is have been the standard bearer for 100 years.  Just ask your friends in Europe how well this demand driven machine has worked to stimulate the economy.  Your deficit deserves aside, you have now stimulated the base in America to spring forward a grass roots movement among tax payors called the TEA PARTY.  You may have missed the news because you only get part of it from the NYT.

The question we need to ask ourselves, eventually at least, is what motivated this self-destructive behavior. What prompted us to smack ourselves?

The truth - an uncomfortable one - is that our hearts have hardened and we've become even more selfish. We're no longer interested in broadly-shared prosperity, but in extracting as much from our planet and one another as possible while giving as little as we can back. This Randian philosophy is much more irascible than a single policy like austerity, and is thus much more deeply engrained.

When you're fundamentally convinced of something - when your soul embodies it - logical reason won't do any good. So expect the self-harm to continue.

And what types of jobs have been created? The real unemployment may be at about 12.6%, based on workers who have given up trying to find full time positions ( http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/10/03/real-jobs-numbers-sad-state_n_5... ). The labor force participation rate is defined as the percentage of the civilian noninstitutional population 16 and over working or looking for work. It is largely determined by demography, most notably the share of the adult population of prime working age, typically 25 to 54. That rate is now 62.7% which is the lowest since the 1970s.

"Sadly, this strategy worked wonders in the recent midterms, even as it did nearly immeasurable damage to much of the middle class these last several years."   Sadder still is that incumbent democrats kept quiet and ran away from the President's successes.

And all the screaming from the rabid Right about job-killing this and job-killing that...the 1%ers have done quite remarkably well for themselves with all this 'regulation' and burdensome taxation. Someone donates 1 million dollars to a conservative campaign or cause. Really? The expectation is a 5-fold return. But don't raise my taxes one penny. Such hubris.
Let's not forget that the housing bubble and subprime loans started well before Obama took office, and both Democrats and Republicans are to blame for setting up that house of cards.

Let's please not forget that many of the austerity policies inflicted on America were part of a calculated "anything but Obama" political posture initiated from the right for their own political aims.
Efforts at fiscal relief were met by obstructionism, gov't shutdown, curtailing unemployment benefits, red states refusal of stimulus funds, etc.. The political calculation appears to have been to sabotage the economy and hang the mess around the President's neck.
Sadly, this strategy worked wonders in the recent midterms, even as it did nearly immeasurable damage to much of the middle class these last several years.
Excellent data-- thank you for posting.

In this same vein, we'd like to add a series of 7 charts coming from Michael Hiltzik of the LATimes:

http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-mh-the-jobs-report-2014060...

showing what's been going on.

As Dr. PK has so often pointed out, chart 5 shows the effects of sequestration (austerity by another name) on government hiring, the lasting legacy of the careening, rolling dumpster fires of a Congress that Boehner has sequentially presided over.

I think that getting hit on the noggin with a bat won't hurt as much as when they take over next year. Then we can expect the most pain to be inflicted upon those that are the most intellectually malleable. For me, I will wear a hardhat and hopefully be resistant.

Dr. K,

The myth of the balanced budget & the harm it does to our society is clearly one of the great mysteries of how we govern ourselves. The myth seems to be embedded in our instincts for survival.

For someone like you who carefully supports your arguments for restoring an economy from a contraction in output that inflicts a lot of misery on most of our society, and now, even the recovery seems to further concentrate the wealth & incomes of our economy, it must be frustrating.

After listening to the arguments for reducing the Deficit for most of the Obama term, sometimes, from your academic colleagues, it makes me wonder about our system.

Banging your head with a baseball bat was a good image but you know well that even our most elite institutions offered the deficit reduction & cutbacks in government spending during the depth of the contraction. What were & are they thinking? The US case seemed to be special because even after Obama called for a stimulus to counter job hemorrhaging & foreclosures, there are still those who believe that it was a bad move. The first midterm election in 2010 that brought the Tea Party reformers to town along with the "cut the deficit meetings that some of our very serious policy types joined in the call for cutting the Deficit. This resulted in the sequester and cliff hanging government stoppages in order to not increase the debt limit. Clearly,the stupidest baseball bats knocks in the annals of government fiscal policy.

I read the print edition out here in the North, so the year in pictures has often been a highlight of my year. It arrived in print today as part of my Sunday NYT, delivered by dogsled (not). What a Sad Sack, Debbie Downer edition of photos! I think the editorial staff need a trip to land where the men are good lookin' and the children above average. Or Prozak.

The farmer's lives were ruined and they had no hope. It is the social injustice perpetrated by for-profit colonial-style agricultural corporations and the  so-called non-profit agencies that aid and abet those corporations that should be criminalized.

I think you've misunderstood the main point of the article: The fact that attempted suicide is a crime not only prevents a discussion of the social, economic and psychological causes, but creates a vested interest amongst
corrupt policemen and politicians to do nothing.
Agree with Einstein here (pun intended). But to blame farmer suicide on transnational corporations and politicians is simplistic and naive.

In 2010, 15,963 farmers in India committed suicide.

The author is going to argue for the 'right' to commit suicide rather than argue for solutions to the social and economic injustice created by transnational corporations and corrupt politicians forcing GMO seeds on the poor farmers. The farmers lived were ruined and they had no hope.

It is absurd to equate 'a right to suicide' with democracy. Of course, no one should be punished for attempted suicide. Look at the root cause of these horrifying tragedies and fight for the democratic rights of your people so they do not become suicide victims.
Maybe 9/11 caused the NYT to elevate photo journalism, something missing for this reader of the paper in the 90's and before.

Exactly 1400 years ha? Wouldn't that coincide with the birth of Islam?
It's not the clerics you have a problem with. It's with anything 'non-persian' namely Arab and Islam. The clerics have, unfortunately, failed to quell that rampant racism and notions of "Perisan Supremacy" that exist in Iran and among most persian diaspora. Clerics are bad alright but there ain't no glory in the nativism and racism of the Shah and the likes.

The farmer's lives were ruined and they had no hope. It is the social injustice perpetrated by for-profit colonial-style agricultural corporations and the  so-called non-profit agencies that aid and abet those corporations that should be criminalized.

Layoffs of workers in the public sector at the state and local level have basically ended but Republican bats at the federal level are probably at the ready when Republicans take control of Congress in 2015. McConnell and Boehner are not about to abandon the obstructionist strategy that gave them both houses of Congress, with an epic majority in the House of Representatives.

With money still so cheap and the deficit rapidly declining, investment in infrastructure, education and research and development would get the economy really humming, but that's never been the Republican agenda with President Obama in the White House.

Looking at the five presidencies preceding Obama's, over a million public sector jobs were created by all of them, even by one-termers like Carter & Bush I. Reagan, that small government guy, created almost 1,500,000 in his second term alone. Obama is still in negative territory on public sector job creation and Congressional Republicans will want to keep him there until the next election.
If only! I hope!

Correction, William: If you had read The Egg and I, or saw the movie, you would know that Ma and Pa Kettle resided in rural WA State and not Kansas. Otherwise, I agree 100% with what you wrote.

Sleepless from Seattle

In 2016, Hillary Clinton and --probably moreso-- Bill Clinton will explain the positives of the Obama economy, while the GOP debates ideology and border fences in its primaries. At the same time, the Clintons will incorporate the pro-Middle-Class Elizabeth Warren message -- as much as they can swallow-- while the GOP tries to move on Capital Gains reform.

It's too bad Democrats only seem able to shape the debate every four years. For me, this is one of the bigger disappointments with Obama. And, within his party, he's not even the biggest offender.

Smart Republicans knew that their characterization of President Obama's economic policies as "profligate spending," "job-killing deficits" and other nonsense was a pack of lies. But they promulgated it anyway to an ignorant public that knew nothing about macroeconomics. The really stupid Republicans who didn't know more than their constituencies went right along with this pernicious party line. The inappropriate analogy to kitchen-table economics was palatable to Ma and Pa Kettle in rural Kansas, and when echoed by Rush, Fox News and the rest of the red-meat right-wing crowd it seemed to explain why they were hurting. In fact they were hurting because there wasn't nearly enough government stimulus. But the Calvinist ethic dies hard. Spending=bad; saving=good was the simplistic mantra fed to the voters.

To be sure, Democrats didn't do anywhere nearly enough to explain the economic facts to the public. They were cowed by the tidal wave of Republican misrepresentation and calumny. It is a miracle that we have begun to emerge from the nightmare economy of the Bush years. President Obama didn't--couldn't do more in this political climate, but his administration will be remembered as the one that pulled us out of the Republican swamp. If voters will only wake up and understand what ridiculous stories they have been fed for the last decade and a half, we might have a chance to continue to put things right in 2016.
RT has the span and impact of a gnat.
Let's print much more then? Oh by the way, print me a half a mill.? Thank you. You need my account number?

Those of us who glance at Russia Today know they keep saying that the US has a fiat currency and is printing vast amounts of money for quantitative easing. What they are preaching is right out of Ayn Rand, who kept saying the only valid currency was 24K gold.

Of course, Russia Today is trying desperately to convince everyone to panic and flee the dollar so the US economy will collapse.

Anyone who understands anything about economics should recognise that Prof Krugman is right, while the anti-Krugmen (e.g., Republicans) are trying to follow the advice of Russia Today.

And the only goal of Russia Today is to destroy the US economy.
And regardless of how improbable, they took over the Senate with nary a whimper by thr President's party.

"Now what?"

Isn't that obvious? To attribute the economic success to the bold austerian action of the Republican House!

Precisely because most people don't see through the lies, I'm unable to share your optimism that the facts are catching up with the lies. Would that it were so! But, while we can debate the reasons, I'm afraid that the malicious sliming of the ACA and all the rest is so baked into the cake at this point that the truth hasn't got a prayer.

comments.userLocation: Lost in the wilds of Maryland
comments.commentBody:
For 6 yrs., the Republicans have occupied themselves telling everyone minute by minute how terrible everything is in America. They have blamed all this terribleness (hey, I know that's not grammatical) on Barack Obama. Now what?

Part of the Republican goal during the first four years was to try to ensure that the economic recovery was weak. Naming the national debt as the number one problem, they hoped to knock off programs like Social Security and Medicare, to take them down several notches and make them less of a threat, if ever they were, to taxes on the rich. Now what?

If the economy had gone back in the tank, that would have been wonderful for the Republicans, since everything, you see, was Obama's fault to start with. Now what?

A few yrs. ago, Obama's policies on energy were blamed for high gasoline prices. Now that regular gas is under $2.50 a gallon in many areas, that naysaying chorus is strangely silent. If Obama was to blame then, does he get credit now? Nope.

Keystone XL was supposed to be the grand symbol of how shortsighted Obama was, holding back the creation of a few dozen permanent jobs by not immediately approving the pipeline. Now what?

Obamacare was supposed to wreck the nation. In Republican eyes, there is still "hope". Now what?

The Republicans have discovered that no one pays attention to facts any more, that 47% or so, led by the 1%, will believe ANYTHING they say. The facts, however, are slowly catching up with the lies. Now what?

Doug Terry

The author states that "For invulnerabilist views, what matters is only the present" and also that if this invulnerabilism is practiced, Buddhists believe that the "end of suffering will follow."

Well, not quite, because while they certainly anticipate the end of suffering, they don't mean in THIS life, so they can hardly be said to be living in the present. The end of suffering is thought to come only when the cycle of reincarnation is finally broken, which can take many lifetimes. In this sense these religions that the author believes tout living in the present are actually a lot less present oriented than, say, Christianity, in which the person can actually anticipate an afterlife that will occur at most a few decades from now.

My theory is that the wealthy oligarchs are trying to drive us to depression - so much so that they can buy the whole USA with the money they have looted from our once-up[on-a-time democracy.

And I agree with all your points.

Agreed, but I don't think the GOP wants to completely strangle the the people and the economy.

I'd say their actions are more like squeezing the fruit produced to extract the juice and deliver it to their rich benefactors. This leaves the pulp and rind for the workers to sustain them to produce more fruit.

S,

So run Warren in 2016 and we'll see what the voters want. Talk is cheap.

The Grand Old Prevaricators and their European Austerians are committed to upside-down logic and economics until wages are permanently feudalized and vaporized into a de minimis expense.

They are completely committed to maintaining their contrived permanent wage depression that lords corporate profits into the permanent stratosphere at complete worker expense.

Middle-class and low-income American wages have completely flat-lined while corporate profits are soaring.

In 2013, corporate after-tax profits were a record-breaking 11.2% of GDP.

Between 1946 and 2010, after-tax corporate profits always remained below 10% of GDP, but 2013 was the fourth consecutive year in which corporate profits exceeded 10% of national income.

The Republicans of course have perfected their patented carnival-barking dog-whistles about the catastrophic evils of the ACA, the President's pigmentation and faux 'uncertainty', but the evidence is in in America; business adores President Obama...and refuses to admit it.

What would you expect of the GOP, which is committed to redistributing increased worker productivity 100% to its narcissistic CEO patrons ?

Remember, the only American Death Panels are unexpanded-Medicaid states run by the Republican Governors Association and the entire Republican-Austerian Congress that has repeatedly tried to assassinate the economy and worker wages with government suffocation of tax revenues and basic services.

The GOP loves to strangle people and economies.

The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan will cost the US between 9 and 12 TRILLION dollars until the last veteran dies, because of the cost of the unbudgeted wars and the cost of care for wounded vets. Look for much of our debt within those figures. Thanks Cheney, Rumsfeld and George the Lesser.

Len,

I think I can finally answer your question. You are right we don't need to worry about our debt today. It doesn't matter how much we borrow. Looking at the fall of the Russian Ruble as the classic response to watering the currency, we don't need to worry at all until there is some other currency above the dollar for everyone to flee to.

Do you know if or when that will occur? Because if there is a choice you will have a problem.
Richard - Yes and an asteroid may hit NYC or Stateline NV or Princeton,NJ. I think I will worry more about the asteroid.

Obama's budgets thus far have added 6 trillion dollars to the federal debt, and in his first term, borrowed money accounted for almost one out of every three dollars spent.   That is not austerity.  It is deficit spending on a massive scale.  But I begin to see how the theory works.  If deficit spending subsequently leads to economic growth, then it worked.  If it doesn't, then the level of spending was inadequate, and more spending is required.

Boulder has laws prohibiting building from being built that are too tall, inhibiting views of the mountains. Apartment buildings exist in Boulder, but they aren't super tall, and there are very few of them. Most people live in houses. The zoning laws prohibit the city from expanding any further west up into the mountains, so the city can only expand east.

Spence, it's entirely possible we will destroy ourselves and societies as we know them before we figure this out. Hopefully any survivors will have a longer view of the future but I doubt it. Will be another dog eat dog whatever. I'm sure it's financially and technically possible to save most of us if we really wanted. Too many don't seem to want to and we vote greedy simple minded sociopaths into office for some perceived short term gain. Hoping we can get out before it all collapses, by various means. All manipulated now by a small number of very wealthy, high influence people.

Imagine the joy I had voting for Amanda Curtiss (high school math teacher) last month for senator. She was a fill in for the appointed John Walsh busted with War College plagarism by not listing his sources. Of course no pressure when you've been a National Guard commander in Iraq and get offered War College. Which is OK if you are already a senator it seems. I never thought that much of Walsh but he was a democrat and better than any current republican. Amanda had 11 weeks to campaign and got 40% of the votes. Of course she lost to Steve Daines who spent 7,000,000 to her 700,000. She could be the real deal someday.

This is the real economy

If the middle/lower class doesn’t feel the recovery, does it count? If wages have been stagnant since 2007 and in some cases lower today, should you gloat? If most of the jobs created are low wage, part-time jobs, will these people rise above poverty?

When Congress/Administration signs TPP more jobs will be shipped overseas. This is the way the plutocracy wants it. Capital flows to where the cost of labor is cheapest. That means U.S. jobs will keep shrinking as companies maximize their gains across the world. Both parties are guilty and this will accelerate job growth stagnation and low wages.

Meanwhile, income inequality skyrockets, the 2nd Gilded Age has arrived for the selected few - top 1%, billion dollar businesses and Wall St. For a majority of Americans, not so much.

In 1952, the corporate income tax accounted for 33 percent of all federal tax revenue. Today, despite record-breaking profits, corporate taxes bring in less than 9 percent. Can America continue to fund tax subsidies, inversion, tax breaks/heaven and other tax loopholes for billion dollar companies and still prosper as a nation?

Our nation is heading in the wrong direction while our MIA Congress seem blind to these trends. Congress should be vilified for their ineptness and held accountable for their bad decisions, but they won’t. Instead, we have a new batch of big, bad Foxes - ready to watch the hen house and exploit the system.

Krugman has more than convinced me that national/global macroeconomics have little bearing on individual debt.  We have 17 trillion now, a staggering sum.  But what is our GDP?  And what is the outstanding debt in derivatives and like?  1000 times that?  Governments can survive large debts long as they manage policies that promote the well being of their citizens.  Unlike individuals who most would be bankrupt within a year operating the same way.  Growth is the way they do it.  Many of us understand unsustainable growth forever in our current path is impossible.  But growth can be sustainable in very different directions.  I think we may be too late to go in those directions.  Overpopulation, greed, and inability to feed 7 billion people could doom us before we figure it out.

One way we self-inflict wounds is by taking in too much debt. Whether you are a corporation, an individual, or a government, you are inflicting long term pain for short term gain.

Corporations, U.S. govt, and individuals have all increased their debt. But we only look at the other side of the ledger, the growth that was paid for by this debt, and congratulate ourselves for a job well done.

Grover Norquist and Sen. Tom Coburn (R-OK), whose life work appeared to be to prevent the government from doing anything for the public--even those in the most need--will be utterly forgotten in U.S. history. They and their ilk have brought shame to our nation, and underscored the brute fact that Republicans have hard hearts and absolutely no understanding of economic policy. Deny, deny and obstruct is not a policy; it is an attack on the nation's prosperity.
For Republicans, the only "entitlement program" worth funding is the military.

As a conservative I pretty much agree with you that George Bush was a failure economically.  He spent a great deal of money foolishly.  However, just because he was wrong, is there any reason to use his stupid policies to defend Obama's stupid policies?

Let's be clear about a key point in this discussion: for 8 years George Walker Bush's government increased spending more than any of the 6 presidents before him; his final 4 years alone he increased discretionary outlays 48%. With the blessing of Republican Chambers they spent almost twice as much Clinton: 53% to Clinton's 12.5%.

Conservatives defend themselves with the strawman argument that entitlement programs grew too fast. But discretionary spending accelerated even more and during Bush’s two terms grew 96% from 2002 to 2009.

Conservatives say our security demanded it. But non-defense spending also increased and the overall rise of discretionary spending showed that Conservatives were unwilling to make trade-offs in budgeting.

Bush and his Congresses allowed the addition of thousands of new federal subsidy programs to 1,816 subsidy programs in the federal budget by 2008 that put hundreds of billions of dollars every year into special interest groups in state government, the businesses sector, nonprofits, and individuals.

Yet the moment Obama was elected Conservatives were suddenly all born again Tea Party members obsessed with denying spending at the one key time we SHOULD have been spending:
* interest rates were very low
* unemployment very high
* infrastructure and social demand was critical

Barack will be shown to have an awful lot for many with very little help much to the shame of our nation.
.
